main_text:
Grammar and Meaning
10. Death


As Schlick was leaving class on June 22, 1936, he was shot four times
in the legs and abdomen by Johann Nelböck, a former philosophy
student who had been threatening Schlick for several years. In fact,
Nelböck had been confined in an asylum for observation and
diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenic. Eventually, other factors
–both social and political- emerged which may also have
influenced Nelböck. The number of possible motivations make it
nearly impossible to fully understand what was in Nelböck’s mind
at the time of his murderous actions.  But the result of his misdeed
is clear: with the death of Moritz Schlick, philosophy lost one of its
most creative thinkers. See Stadler 2001 (Part 2, Sec. 3–3.2) for a
comprehensive account of Schlick’s death.
